natural problem: How many paths are there from $C$ to $B$, if every step must be up or to the right?[asy]size(4cm,4cm);int w=6;int h=5;int i;pen p=fontsize(9);for (i=0; i<h; ++i){draw((0,i) -- (w-1,i));}for (i=0; i<w; ++i){draw((i, 0)--(i,h-1));}dot("$A$", (0,0), SW, p);dot("$C$", (1,2), NE, p);dot("$B$", (w-1,h-1), NE, p);[/asy]
natural solution: There are 4 steps to the right, and 2 steps up. These 6 steps can be made in any order, so the answer is $\binom{6}{4} = \boxed{15}$.

assumes h0 : "A = (0, 0)"

 ### Proof

 *)

a_8.formal problem:
theorem
fixes A B C :: "nat \<times> nat"
assumes h0 : "A = (0, 0)"
and h1 : "B = (5, 4)"
and h2 : "C = (1, 2)"
and h3 : "\<forall> (x, y) \<in> {A, B, C}. x \<le> 5 \<and> y \<le> 4"
and h4 : "\<forall> path. path \<in> {C..B} \<longrightarrow> (\<forall> (x1, y1) (x2, y2) \<in> path. x1 \<le> x2 \<and> y1 \<le> y2)"
shows  "card {path. path \<in> {C..B} \<and> (\<forall> (x1, y1) (x2, y2) \<in> path. x1 \<le> x2 \<and> y1 \<le> y2)} = 15"
a_8.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 How many paths are there from $C$ to $B$, if every step must be up or to the right?[asy]size(4cm,4cm);int w=6;int h=5;int i;pen p=fontsize(9);for (i=0; i<h; ++i){draw((0,i) -- (w-1,i));}for (i=0; i<w; ++i){draw((i, 0)--(i,h-1));}dot("$A$", (0,0), SW, p);dot("$C$", (1,2), NE, p);dot("$B$", (w-1,h-1), NE, p);[/asy] The final Answer is 15
 ### Proof
 There are 4 steps to the right, and 2 steps up. These 6 steps can be made in any order, so the answer is $\binom{6}{4} = \boxed{15}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes A B C :: "nat \<times> nat"
assumes h0 : "A = (0, 0)"
and h1 : "B = (5, 4)"
and h2 : "C = (1, 2)"
and h3 : "\<forall> (x, y) \<in> {A, B, C}. x \<le> 5 \<and> y \<le> 4"
and h4 : "\<forall> path. path \<in> {C..B} \<longrightarrow> (\<forall> (x1, y1) (x2, y2) \<in> path. x1 \<le> x2 \<and> y1 \<le> y2)"
shows  "card {path. path \<in> {C..B} \<and> (\<forall> (x1, y1) (x2, y2) \<in> path. x1 \<le> x2 \<and> y1 \<le> y2)} = 15"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_8.informal problem: Consider three points A, B, and C in a grid with non-negative integer coordinates, where A=(0,0), B=(5,4), and C=(1,2). Find the number of distinct paths from point C to point B such that each step in the path moves either right or up (never left or down), and all points visited in the path have coordinates (x,y) where x ≤ 5 and y ≤ 4. The final answer is 15.

a_9.formal problem:
theorem
fixes paths :: nat
assumes h0 : "paths = (\<Sum>(i, j) \<in> {(i, j). i \<ge> 1 \<and> i \<le> 6 \<and> j \<ge> 2 \<and> j \<le> 5}. binomial (i + j - 3) (i - 1))"
shows  "paths = 15"
a_9.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 How many paths are there from $C$ to $B$, if every step must be up or to the right?[asy]size(4cm,4cm);int w=6;int h=5;int i;pen p=fontsize(9);for (i=0; i<h; ++i){draw((0,i) -- (w-1,i));}for (i=0; i<w; ++i){draw((i, 0)--(i,h-1));}dot("$A$", (0,0), SW, p);dot("$C$", (1,2), NE, p);dot("$B$", (w-1,h-1), NE, p);[/asy] The final Answer is 15
 ### Proof
 There are 4 steps to the right, and 2 steps up. These 6 steps can be made in any order, so the answer is $\binom{6}{4} = \boxed{15}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes paths :: nat
assumes h0 : "paths = (\<Sum>(i, j) \<in> {(i, j). i \<ge> 1 \<and> i \<le> 6 \<and> j \<ge> 2 \<and> j \<le> 5}. binomial (i + j - 3) (i - 1))"
shows  "paths = 15"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_9.informal problem: How many paths are there in a grid of size 6 by 5, starting from the top-left corner (1,1) and ending at the bottom-right corner (6,5), if you can only move right or down? The final answer is 15.
